Choice.Value: Allowing testers to confirm if the implemented application is acceptable
Defining the process a user will perform to accomplish a given task
Defining a common understanding of scope among the business, users, and project team
Determining which technologies should be used for the application

FillIn.Answer: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\cf1\b\f0\fs29 Mockup prototype\b0\par \b Correct:\b0 A mockup prototype, also called a horizontal prototype, fills in the gaps that exist in the understanding of the UI.\par \par \b Vertical prototype\b0\par \b Incorrect:\b0 A vertical prototype covers a vertical slice of the entire application. These requirements consider only gaps in the understanding of the UI.\par \par \b Proof-of-concept prototype\b0\par \b Incorrect:\b0 A proof-of-concept prototype validates the application\rquote s architecture and technology. These requirements consider only gaps in the understanding of the UI.\par \par \b Reference architecture prototype\b0\par \b Incorrect:\b0 A reference architecture is another term for a proof-of-concept prototype. These requirements consider only gaps in the understanding of the UI.\par }

Choice.Value: Define the screens, their types, and their complexities.
Create a working prototype of each unique element defined by the application.
Update the requirements based on the findings from your prototype.
A number of gaps were identified in the requirements.
The use cases were validated as correct and sufficient.
Certain areas of the application were exposed as requiring additional focus in terms of design.
The new technologies that were recommended worked just as expected.
